awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG: Connecting communities with real-time data collection and downscaled climate risk models to improve water quality and sustain salt marshes in the Buzzards Bay Watershed
awd_abstract_narration:
Coastal communities face enormous challenges managing water resources in the face of climate change. Degraded water quality driven by excess nutrients, combined with rising sea levels, increased river flooding, higher temperatures, and greater climate variation will increase nutrient delivery to coastal waters and impair the ability of salt marshes to sustain themselves. Many municipalities share coastal waters, with nutrient loading often originating from watersheds farther inland. Community management of water quality and salt marsh loss are inhibited by two critical factors. First, conditions that lead to the biggest impacts occur infrequently, and climate change will increase this variability. Second, data and information on these events are not well captured by existing monitoring systems, making it difficult for managers to identify appropriate solutions. Emerging technologies have the potential to provide dynamic information on water quality, marshes and climate in ways that can provide more comprehensive information and connect across communities managing water resources. New automated sensors can be deployed across multiple locations to provide time-series and information to better identify impacts and potential solutions. Downscaled climate models can predict climate changes at local scales. However, technologies will only be adopted if the information they produce is both useful and useable as well as trusted and accepted by communities.  

This project will investigate the potential for continuously-collected water quality information and regional climate models to support management of water quality and salt mashes in the Buzzards Bay Watershed in coastal Massachusetts. Technology developers and stakeholders will co-design data collection strategies to improve local water resources research The project will engage scientists and members of the community who manage, regulate, and advocate for water quality and marshes to determine: (1) What information is needed to better identify impacts to water quality and salt marshes and to guide water and marsh management? (2) What new sensor technologies, field applications, and climate model projections could be combined to produce the knowledge needed? and (3) How can these new technologies be best deployed and managed to create a smart and connected community? Workshops and interactions among scientists and community members will identify the highest-priority and highest-value potential future uses of new sensor technologies and identify the climate risks of greatest interest to the community. The outcomes from the workshops will be used organize future research to pilot the priority technologies and test conceptual models of how the communities use the new technology.

por.por_cntn:
Coastal communities face large challenges monitoring the quality of water resources at the local and frequent time scales that are necessary to identify water quality problems and to document improvements following investments in programs or infrastructure to improve water quality. Traditional water quality monitoring is conducted by periodic collection of physical water quality sampling. However, conditions that lead to the large water quality and biological impacts (such as periods of low oxygen during heat waves or following periods of high river discharge) occur infrequently and are not well captured by existing monitoring programs that sample only periodically. This makes it hard for citizens to document problems and for managers to identify appropriate water quality actions. New continuously-recording water quality sensors now have the potential be deployed across multiple locations to provide time-series and information to better identify water quality impacts and potential solutions.

This short-term planning project conducted a series of workshops with citizens, key members of organizations concerned with water quality, municipal representatives, and regulators, and sensor engineers in the coastal communities around Buzzards Bay, Massachusetts. The aim of the workshops was to identify what water quality sensor technologies have the greatest potential to generate information that would be used by people in these representative groups. Stakeholders in the workshops identified compromised water quality caused by nitrogen runoff to coastal waters as their number one water quality concern. They also identified low oxygen and associated odors and fish kills associated as a primary concern and one that could be addressed by deployment of recording oxygen sensors. The workshops also identified several important new challenges that might be generated by new sensors. These included (1) they generate large amounts of data that many municipal and community groups that conduct water quality monitoring are ill-equipped to handle, (2) they threaten to displace the people (often volunteers) who collect traditional samples, and (3) agencies that use monitoring data to make regulatory decisions typically set criteria and thresholds based on traditional rather than sensor-based water quality information.

Based the stakeholder workshops the project developed approaches to examining how the transition from traditional water quality sampling ?grab sampling? to continuous sensor sampling will influence both the groups collecting the monitoring data and the data users. A proposed pilot study will deploy small and inexpensive by highly accurate water oxygen sensors from both fixed platforms and attached to low-cost mobile ?gliders? that move around coastal embayments. The study will interview volunteers who currently collect monitoring data to determine the extent to which their engagement changes with sensor deployment. It will conduct focus groups with citizens, non-profit, and municipal stakeholders within Buzzards Bay coastal communities to test how the locations at which sensors are deployed influence their views about the quality and relevance of the data. And it will conduct focus groups with regulators to identify the ways that new sensor-collected data are likely to be incorporated into identification of new water quality thresholds and new water quality regulations.
